subject: Home & DIY
title: How IKEA Changed Everything
description: A micro-lesson that makes How IKEA Changed Everything usable.

hook.text: IKEA sells more furniture than any company in history. Their secret isn't designâ€”it's the flat cardboard box.

buildup.text: In 1956, an IKEA worker cut a table's legs off to fit it in a car. Kamprad turned that accident into a system.

discovery.text: Flat-pack ships in compact boxes, slashing transport costs 80%. Customers assemble it, eliminating labor costs.

twist.text: IKEA designs products around box dimensions first, then makes them look good. Packaging drives the engineering.

climax.text: With 460 stores in 63 countries, IKEA furnishes more homes worldwide than any designer, movement, or era in history.

punchline.text: One flat box furnished the entire planet.

quiz.question: What inspired IKEA's flat-pack furniture concept?
options: A worker removed table legs to fit them in a car
A fire destroyed their warehouse of assembled furniture
Swedish tax law favored unassembled goods
